title: Isaias Live Updates: Storm Grazes Florida and Takes Aim at the Carolinas
description: Storm watches have been extended as far north as New England. The storm is on a track to reach land on Monday, with heavy rain and the potential for damaging floods.
content: Floridians along the state’s Atlantic coast hunkered down on Sunday as Tropical Storm Isaias plowed northward just offshore, whipping the state with high winds, rain and the threat of flash floods as it went.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: To Break a Horse, and a Woman
description: How do prey animals stay safe in a world out to get them? And how would I?
content: Horses talk, but not like Mr. Ed. A horse may be trained to respond to “whoa” and “giddy up,” but if you speak to a horse, you’re not speaking in horse. They converse mostly through body language, and their most visible correspondence is a sign language of ears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: TikTok Ban? Creators and Fans Are Big Mad
description: The uncertainty over the future of the wildly popular video app has brought chaos to its user community — and to the entertainment and advertising industries as well.
content: It was a weekend of chaos on TikTok — unleashed on Friday night when President Trump said, while aboard Air Force One, that he might ban the video app.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Law to Cut Drug Sentences Is No Help for Some Inmates
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 2, 2020.
content: “It’s like the luck of the draw. You’ve got people sitting in prison during a pandemic, and it’s not supposed to come down to who your judge is. It’s supposed to come down to the law.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Armstrong
title: Mets’ Yoenis Cespedes Opts Out of 2020 Season
description: Cespedes had failed to show up to the ballpark in Atlanta for the Mets’ game against the Braves on Sunday, and the team did not know his whereabouts. After the game, they announced his decision to opt out.
content: When Mets Manager Luis Rojas realized Yoenis Cespedes, one of his most powerful hitters, was not at the ballpark in Atlanta on Sunday morning, he sent his outfielder a text message and followed with a phone call. Cespedes did not reply.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Sydney Ember
title: Elizabeth Warren’s Evolution on Race Brought Her Here
description: Ms. Warren, a racially progressive politician, is one of a handful of white women still under serious consideration to become Joe Biden’s running mate.
content: When Liz Herring arrived at George Washington University as a freshman in 1966, she entered a capital city in the throes of the civil rights movement. Just three years after a quarter-million people had crowded the National Mall to hear the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Congress was debating civil rights legislation as violent protests continued across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benedict Carey
title: Birx Says U.S. Epidemic Is in a ‘New Phase’
description: She and other top health officials in the Trump administration warn states of a deepening spread of the coronavirus, in both rural and urban areas.
content: Dr. Deborah L. Birx, the Trump administration’s coronavirus coordinator, said on Sunday that the nation was in a “new phase” of the coronavirus epidemic that was much more sprawling across the country than last spring’s outbreaks in major cities like New York and Seattle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: NASA Astronauts in SpaceX Capsule Make First Water Landing Since 1975
description: Bob Behnken and Doug Hurley splashed down on Sunday in the Gulf of Mexico in the Crew Dragon spacecraft.
content: The first astronaut trip to orbit by a private company has splashed down safely in the Gulf of Mexico. Two astronauts dropped out of orbit in what was the first water landing by NASA since 1975, when the agency’s crews were still flying in the Apollo modules used for the historic American moon missions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mercedes Lilienthal
title: Driving Across the Globe to Fight Child Trafficking
description: Renée Brinkerhoff has been on a quest, on almost every continent, to use racing “as a platform to do something about” a global scourge. Next stop, Antarctica.
content: It wasn’t until Renée Brinkerhoff’s last of four children departed for college that her life changed forever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nafeeza Yahya-Sakur and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Guyana Swears In New Leader, Resolving Struggle Over Oil Wealth
description: Mohamed Irfaan Ali will manage the flow of billions in new oil revenues, which are reshaping the small South American country and heightened a standoff after elections in March.
content: GEORGETOWN, Guyana — Guyana’s opposition party has won a bitterly contested general election, ending a prolonged political standoff that had crippled investment and heightened ethnic tensions in the small South American nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zabihullah Ghazi and Mujib Mashal
title: Militants Attack Afghan Prison as Brief Cease-Fire Expires
description: The Islamic State reportedly took responsibility for an assault at a time when releasing insurgents from prisons has become a major issue in the Afghan peace process.
content: JALALABAD, Afghanistan — Militants attacked a major prison in eastern Afghanistan on Sunday, detonating a car bomb and waging a gun battle against guards for hours, as dozens of inmates managed to escape, Afghan officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: Is the Subway Risky? It May Be Safer Than You Think
description: New studies in Europe and Asia suggest that riding public transportation is not a major source of transmission for the coronavirus.
content: Five months after the coronavirus outbreak engulfed New York City, riders are still staying away from public transportation in enormous numbers, often because they are concerned that sharing enclosed places with strangers is simply too dangerous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Theatrical Sort
description: Eric Bornstein’s debut puzzle puts us all in a state.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — This is a fun debut from Eric Bornstein with some little patterns sprinkled throughout. I know people realize this, but it’s certainly not easy to construct an easier puzzle. Today is a good example: Notice the precise setup, with straightforward clues for difficult entries and funnier clues for easier words, and the way that difficult and more accessible entries overlap, to give us fewer ways to get locked out of the solve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff
title: Less Sex, More Viewers: Pandemic Boosts Mexico’s Flagging Telenovelas
description: Dismissed as too old-fashioned to compete with streaming services, the melodramas have seen viewership surge from Mexicans seeking the familiar in a distressing time.
content: MEXICO CITY — Mexico’s love affair with melodrama was over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Trump Forecasts His Own Fraud
description: In the president’s world, he is never to blame for failure.
content: This election is in danger of being stolen. By Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis and Shawn Hubler
title: Covid Tests and Quarantines: Colleges Brace for an Uncertain Fall
description: Colleges are racing to reconfigure dorms, expand testing programs and establish detailed social distancing rules. And then, what to do about sex?
content: This month, many colleges around the country plan to welcome back thousands of students into something they hope will resemble normal campus life. But they face challenges unlike any other American institution — containing the coronavirus among a young, impulsive population that not only studies together, but lives together, parties together, and, if decades of history are any guide, sleeps together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azam Ahmed
title: Mexico Seizes Crime Boss El Marro, Under Pressure to Cut Violence
description: While the arrest of José Antonio Yépez delivers a major blow to a cartel, analysts say officials lack a cohesive strategy against debilitating crime.
content: MEXICO CITY — The Mexican federal authorities captured José Antonio Yépez, the criminal boss known as El Marro, on Sunday, landing a major blow against a cartel whose struggle for control helped spur record violence in the midst of the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Florida’s Summer of Dread
description: The coronavirus had entrenched itself in communities from Pensacola to Key West, killing more than 7,000 Floridians. Then came Tropical Storm Isaias.
content: MIAMI — The crowded grocery stores, empty shelves and barren streets of South Florida in the dawning days of the coronavirus pandemic felt unsettlingly familiar: They resembled the rush of preparations and then the tense silence that precede a hurricane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Israeli Court Rebukes Prime Minister’s Son Over Harassing Protest Leaders
description: Yair Netanyahu tweeted the addresses and phone numbers of three men who led protests against his father’s administration. All three said they later received death threats.
content: TEL AVIV — An Israeli court on Sunday ordered Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s older son to stop harassing three people helping to lead protests against his father’s administration after he tweeted out their home addresses and cellphone numbers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Janet Maslin
title: Lady Macbeth in Appalachia, and Other Tales by an American Master
description: With a new collection, “In the Valley,” Ron Rash revisits the monstrous protagonist of “Serena” and plumbs the depths of Southern hearts.
content: Nearly half of Ron Rash’s mesmerizing new story collection is devoted to the eponymous “In the Valley,” a sequel to his 2008 novel “Serena.” If you’ve read that book, you surely remain haunted by its mythic powers. Nominally the Depression-era story of a North Carolina logging heir who returns home from Boston with a daunting new bride, it invested the power-mad Serena Pemberton with otherworldly malign qualities and gave her a big swath of North Carolina’s Appalachian logging country to despoil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: U.S. Small Business Bailout Money Flowed to Chinese-Owned Companies
description: Millions of dollars of Paycheck Protection Program loans went to China-backed businesses in critical sectors, a study found.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump has blamed China for the coronavirus pandemic and the ensuing economic crisis, but as the White House looks to stabilize small businesses in the United States, the rescue effort has had an unintended beneficiary: Chinese companies.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: August 2, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, August 2, 2020.
content: An article on Page 10 about the Netflix documentary series “Last Chance U” refers imprecisely to coach John Beam. He identifies as multiracial, not white.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: It’s a Book. It’s a Podcast. It’s a Three-Act Play, in Your Ears.
description: Jesse Eisenberg’s audio drama, “When You Finish Saving the World,” is coming to Audible ahead of a film adaptation with Julianne Moore.
content: If you’re missing the chilly joy of ducking into a movie theater on a sweltering day, welcome to the club.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Connected’ and the SpaceX Landing
description: “Radiolab” journalist Latif Nasser hosts a new show on Netflix, and the SpaceX craft makes its return to Earth.
content: CONNECTED Stream on Netflix. As the director of research for “Radiolab,” Latif Nasser has covered all sorts of fascinating stories for the science podcast, like that of a Guantánamo Bay detainee who shares his name, or what the 2016 N.H.L. All-Star Game can teach us about democracy. Now, as the host of this new Netflix show, Nasser will uncover the surprising ways humans are connected to one another, the world and the universe at large. It’s a fascinating topic — one that highlights how a law of numerical probability applies to classical music, social media and tax fraud, or how a shipwreck laid the ground work for weather forecasting and cloud computing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Vaccine, TikTok, SpaceX: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Elijah Walker
title: Midwest, School Reopenings, Summer Gardens: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Grimes
title: Wilford Brimley, ‘Cocoon’ Star and Quaker Oats Pitchman, Is Dead at 85
description: Recognizable by his walrus mustache, the actor specialized in playing cantankerous characters in “Absence of Malice,” “The Natural” and other films.
content: Wilford Brimley, a portly actor with a walrus mustache who found his niche playing cantankerous coots in “Absence of Malice,” “The Natural,” “Cocoon” and other films, died on Saturday in a hospital in St. George, Utah. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: How the Media Could Get the Election Story Wrong
description: We may not know the results for days, and maybe weeks. So it’s time to rethink “election night.”
content: Picture this Thanksgiving: turkey, football (maybe), tenser-than-usual interactions with relatives. And perhaps a new tradition: finding out who actually won the presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Lord & Taylor Files for Bankruptcy as Retail Collapses Pile Up
description: The department store, which traces its roots to 1826, was struggling before the coronavirus hit. Its owner, the clothing rental start-up Le Tote, also filed for bankruptcy.
content: Lord & Taylor, the floundering department store company that traces its roots to 1826, on Sunday became the latest retailer to file for bankruptcy protection as the coronavirus outbreak accelerates the demise of chains that were already teetering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Russia Sets Mass Vaccination for October After Shortened Trial
description: The announcement raised concerns that Russia would begin inoculations and declare victory in the race for a coronavirus vaccine without fully testing its product.
content: MOSCOW — Russia plans to launch a nationwide vaccination campaign in October with a coronavirus vaccine that has yet to complete clinical trials, raising international concern about the methods the country is using to compete in the global race to inoculate the public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $600,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Arrests Over Illicit Party Boat With 170 Guests Cruising Around N.Y.C.
description: It was yet another symbol of reckless socializing during the pandemic: The Liberty Belle was dinged for violating distancing rules, and its owners were accused of running an unlicensed bar, the authorities said.
content: The Liberty Belle, a riverboat with four bars, three outdoor decks and space for 600 guests, has been touted by its operators as a “favorite venue” of New Yorkers who hold parties, fund-raisers and other trendy events on the water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac, Ana Swanson and Maggie Haberman
title: Microsoft Says It’ll Continue Pursuit of TikTok
description: The announcement came after the company consulted with President Trump, who has threatened to ban the app and expressed national security concerns about it in recent weeks.
content: Microsoft said on Sunday that it would continue to pursue the purchase of TikTok in the United States after consulting with President Trump, clearing the way for a potential blockbuster deal between the software giant and the viral social media phenomenon.
source.name: The New York Times

title: To Ensure That Our Election Is Fair and Open
description: Readers urge vigilance against threats to the democratic process.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: U.S. Identifies Some of the Mysterious Seeds Mailed From China
description: The 14 varieties identified include common ones, such as hibiscus, morning glory and lavender. Still, experts warned recipients not to plant them.
content: A federal agency said it had identified 14 types of plants from unsolicited packages of seeds that appeared to have been mailed from China, revealing a “mix of ornamental, fruit and vegetable, herb and weed species.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Women Doctors Ask: Who Gets to Decide What’s ‘Professional’?
description: With #MedBikini, doctors are pushing back against what many see as sexist expectations of appearance and behavior.
content: — Carmen Simmons, 27, a fourth-year medical student
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Maggie Haberman
title: Kayleigh McEnany Heckles the Press. Is That All?
description: President Trump does not always watch her briefings, and even his allies say she risks being known more for “hitting the press with a two-by-four” than advancing his priorities.
content: WASHINGTON — For the first half of his term, President Trump treated the White House press briefing as must-see television. From his small dining room off the Oval Office, he kept close watch over his first two press secretaries as they battled with journalists, defended his performance and often tried to rewrite history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Stephenson
title: How Joe Arpaio’s Fate in Arizona Could Be a Window Into Trump’s
description: The polarizing former sheriff of Maricopa County, a stylistic doppelgänger to President Trump, is running for his old office in a state where approval of both men has slid.
content: PHOENIX — After 24 years of doling out his punitive brand of justice in Arizona’s most populous county, Joe Arpaio, who billed himself as “America’s toughest sheriff,” suffered a landslide defeat in 2016, largely because of his hard-line immigration stances and his own pugnacious defiance, which earned him a criminal conviction for contempt of court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Gillis
title: When Utility Money Talks
description: Corruption scandals in Ohio and Illinois reveal an unsavory underside to the politics of energy.
content: The billion-dollar bailout of one of Ohio’s biggest utilities seemed suspicious from the start. It turns out the F.B.I. was paying attention, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: As Genoa Inaugurates New Bridge, the Feeling Is Bittersweet
description: Built in less than two years to replace the collapsed Morandi bridge, the new span is already a point of pride for Italy. But residents fear it will not be enough to revive their aging port city.
content: GENOA, Italy — Since the dramatic and deadly collapse of the Morandi bridge over the Italian port of Genoa two years ago, builders have worked around the clock, through a judicial investigation and the coronavirus pandemic, so a new bridge could open on time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Crouse
title: Britain Tried to Bring Fans Back to Indoor Sports. That Lasted a Day.
description: The world snooker championship welcomed spectators last week, part of a pilot program that offered hope to other events eager to follow suit. A few hours later, the government pulled the plug.
content: SHEFFIELD, England — The 2020 world snooker championship, which began on Friday, had a familiar feel. The stage of the intimate Crucible Theatre, the event’s home for more than 40 years, was bathed in klieg lights, the green cloth of the snooker tables and the red carpeting so brightly illuminated it was like stepping inside a Skittles bag. Judd Trump was back to defend his title, and for the first time in months, there were fans in the seats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Nordstrom Uses Influencers to Promote Safety and Draw Anxious Shoppers
description: Some retailers are turning to popular social media personalities to detail post-pandemic protocols and boost the allure of visiting their stores.
content: Wendy Nguyen, a fashionable Instagram personality with 1.1 million followers, is regularly tapped by retailers like Macy’s and Banana Republic to promote their wares on social media. They typically want her to take a stylish photo in their apparel and enthuse about their brand and any upcoming sale or product line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Where a Little Mortgage Goes a Long Way
description: Affordable homes can be hard to buy because lenders don’t make much money on small loans. But programs to encourage homeownership can help buyers build wealth.
content: The Shawnee neighborhood in Louisville, Ky., is a paradox: The houses are affordable, but they can be difficult to buy. The prices are so low that most banks and lenders will not bother writing mortgages for them.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘On Female Rage’
description: “I used to insist I didn’t get angry. Not anymore.”
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Apple Fire Leads to Evacuation Order for 7,000 in California
description: The wildfire, near the San Bernardino National Forest east of Los Angeles, was burning out of control on Sunday morning.
content: Firefighters on Sunday night were struggling to control a wildfire 75 miles east of Los Angeles that had burned more than 20,000 acres and destroyed three structures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: ‘Everyone Can Do Better’: Baseball Searches for Blame Amid Outbreaks
description: Major League Baseball’s commissioner put the onus on players to behave more responsibly, but some players and health experts see weaknesses in the league’s safety protocols.
content: With the Major League Baseball season becoming more precarious seemingly by the day amid a slow but steady stream of new coronavirus cases among the teams, the league’s commissioner, Rob Manfred, issued something of a rallying cry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: In St. Louis, Testing Liberal Might Against a Democratic Fixture
description: Cori Bush, an activist backed by the progressive group Justice Democrats, is trying to unseat 10-term Representative William Lacy Clay in a bid to turn protest-movement fervor into hard political power.
content: FERGUSON, Mo. — As an activist who jumped into the political arena after the police shooting of Michael Brown here six years ago, Cori Bush is accustomed to hard fights. She has been maced, shot at with rubber bullets and cloaked in tear gas at so many protests against police brutality that they have blurred together.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Do Learning Pods Endanger Equality?
description: Readers discuss closed schools, pods and inequities.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryce Covert
title: Biden’s Quietly Radical Care Plan
description: The candidate is talking about child care and elder care in the same breath, and making them part of his economic package. Both changes are long overdue.
content: Joe Biden’s recent policy proposal to address the country’s crisis of care didn’t garner major headlines. There were no haphazardly capitalized Trump tweets in response, nor congressional Republicans denouncing it as socialism. But make no mistake: His plan is quietly radical in both its comprehensiveness and its framing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathaniel Popper, Kate Conger and Kellen Browning
title: From Minecraft Tricks to Twitter Hack: A Florida Teen’s Troubled Online Path
description: The teenage “mastermind” of the recent Twitter breach, who had a difficult family life, poured his energy into video games and cryptocurrency.
content: For Graham Ivan Clark, the online mischief-making started early.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Birx Warns That U.S. Epidemic Is in a ‘New Phase’
description: College are preparing to welcome students back to a complicated campus setting. India’s home minister tests positive.
content: Dr. Deborah L. Birx, the Trump administration’s coronavirus coordinator, said on the CNN program “State of the Union” on Sunday that the country is in a “new phase” of the coronavirus pandemic, and that it is much more extensive than the spring outbreaks in major cities like New York and Seattle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Rebecca Halleck
title: Tropical Storm Isaias, Grazing Florida, Takes Aim at Carolinas
description: The Florida coast was spared severe damage on Sunday, but much of the Eastern Seaboard is threatened with flooding rains.
content: ATLANTA — Tropical Storm Isaias buffeted Florida’s eastern edge on Sunday with more heavy rainfall and powerful winds as it skirted the Atlantic Coast, leaving many people bracing for the threat of flash floods, storm surges and even tornadoes as the storm made its way north.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: The Calm Voice Asking Thorny Questions in ‘Death, Sex & Money’
description: In her podcast, Anna Sale inspires her guests to share their darkest thoughts and deepest secrets. The intimate conversations feel more urgent than ever.
content: If you want to know what it feels like to be listened to, if, in our moment of detachment and division, you’ve forgotten the basic pleasure of revealing something delicate about yourself to another person, and of having that person respond by taking a sincere and sustained interest, allow Anna Sale to remind you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: A Group of Pac-12 Football Players Threaten to Opt Out of the Season
description: The athletes from 10 schools said they were dissatisfied with how their universities were handling the coronavirus, an approach they say prioritizes money over safety.
content: Thirteen Pac-12 Conference football players threatened Sunday to opt out of the coming season, saying they would not play until systemic inequities that have been highlighted by college athletics’ response to the coronavirus pandemic were addressed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Drucker and David Enrich
title: Deutsche Bank Opens Review Into Personal Banker to Trump and Kushner
description: The bank will examine a 2013 transaction between the banker, Rosemary Vrablic, and a company part-owned by Jared Kushner.
content: Deutsche Bank has opened an internal investigation into the longtime personal banker of President Trump and his son-in-law, Jared Kushner, over a 2013 real estate transaction between the banker and a company part-owned by Mr. Kushner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Congress, Test Thyself
description: Lawmakers are essential workers. They should start acting like it and protect themselves and the other people who work on Capitol Hill.
content: Representative Louie Gohmert, Republican of Texas, is not the first member of Congress to test positive for the coronavirus. At least 14 lawmakers, hailing from both parties and both chambers, are known to have either tested or been presumed positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allan Kozinn
title: Leon Fleisher, 92, Dies; Spellbinding Pianist With One Hand or Two
description: Unable to use his right hand, he performed pieces written for left hand only, conducted and taught. After 30 years, he made a triumphant two-handed comeback.
content: Leon Fleisher, a leading American pianist in the 1950s and early ’60s who was forced by an injury to his right hand to channel his career into conducting, teaching and mastering the left-hand repertoire, died on Sunday in a hospice in Baltimore.  He was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘As I Started to Walk Away, the Second Man Reached Out His Hand’
description: Giving directions, a noisy Chinatown dining room and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Relief Package Deal Remains Elusive as Impasse Over Jobless Benefits Persists
description: Negotiators acknowledged some progress over the weekend, but said they remained far apart on a number of issues.
content: WASHINGTON — Top Trump administration officials and lawmakers cautioned on Sunday that a deal over a new relief package to help people and businesses weather the coronavirus crisis remained elusive even as the debate over the details of the aid was set to take center stage in the coming week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Immigration Nation’ Review: The Banality of Deportation
description: This Netflix documentary looks at the bureaucracy of immigration enforcement — an intriguing investigation that probably won’t change any minds.
content: If you watch only one documentary about immigration, then by all means make it “Immigration Nation,” a six-hour Netflix series that mixes reporting with an impressive amount of vivid ride-along observation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Conservative U.K. Lawmaker Is Arrested Over Rape Accusations
description: The arrest of the lawmaker, who has not been publicly identified, poses problems for the government of Prime Minister Boris Johnson.
content: A Conservative lawmaker in Britain was arrested this weekend after a former parliamentary employee accused him of raping her, according to British news reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fernando Cheung
title: Why Did Hong Kong Delay Its Election — by a Year?
description: The government blames the pandemic. More likely, it was afraid to lose.
content: HONG KONG — And now, it’s election fraud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: ‘Clean Up This Mess’: The Chinese Thinkers Behind Xi’s Hard Line
description: Chinese academics have been honing the Communist Party’s authoritarian response in Hong Kong, rejecting the liberal ideas of their youth.
content: HONG KONG — When Tian Feilong first arrived in Hong Kong as demands for free elections were on the rise, he said he felt sympathetic toward a society that seemed to reflect the liberal political ideas he had studied as a graduate student in Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: Getting Rich Off the Pandemic
description: Tech executives got grilled in Washington, but their wallets got the last laugh.
content: Welcome to August, everyone. I’m on vacation next week, escaping the subtropical zone of Brooklyn for the sanity-restoring woods of Vermont, so Gillian Friedman will be filling in. Until then, here’s what you need to know in business and tech for the week ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: ‘Thanks for Flying SpaceX’: NASA Astronauts Safely Splash Down After Journey From Orbit
description: Bob Behnken and Doug Hurley returned to Earth in the first water landing by an American space crew since 1975.
content: The first astronaut trip to orbit by a private company parachuted to a safe conclusion in the Gulf of Mexico on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Make Colu Henry’s white bean caprese salad, Yewande Komolafe’s baked tofu with peanut sauce, or the chef Rawlston Williams’s stew chicken.
content: Good morning. Life during the pandemic offers its pleasures only fitfully, but there’s a good tomato getting ready for harvest on my solitary compound-bucketed plant and I’ve been looking forward to it all week. I’m planning on eating it sun-warm and cut into shingles between slices of toast, with a little salt and a bunch of mayonnaise. That’s summer’s greatest sandwich. I can almost taste it now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: As Federal Agents Retreat in Portland, Protesters Return to Original Foe: Local Police
description: While protests around the federal courthouse have remained calm for three consecutive nights, Portland police officers chased demonstrators through the streets near a local precinct.
content: PORTLAND, Ore. — Late on Saturday night, with protests in Portland continuing into their third month, one crowd of demonstrators gathered yet again in front of the city’s fortified federal courthouse while another group traveled miles east to a precinct used by local law enforcement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Doug Glanville
title: Baseball Is Playing for Its Life, and Ours
description: An outbreak of infections soon after reopening has struck a blow at more than just the Marlins.
content: In 1996, my rookie year in the major leagues with the Chicago Cubs, our manager Jim Riggleman often reminded us that we should play for the name on the front of our uniforms, not the name on the back. It was a noble idea — team before self — reinforced by the power big league athletes can feel when they realize they are representing entire cities, states, even countries, and taking a place in a long history of the sport they are so passionate about.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By NASA
title: Several Private Boats Encroach on SpaceX Landing Zone
description: Onlookers circled the SpaceX Crew Dragon capsule as it bobbed in the water after its return to Earth, raising concerns about their possible exposure to toxic propellant fumes from the spacecraft.
content: Onlookers circled the SpaceX Crew Dragon capsule as it bobbed in the water after its return to Earth, raising concerns about their possible exposure to toxic propellant fumes from the spacecraft.
source.name: The New York Times
